desc.p: My portfolio from 2013 is an experiment in new techniques at the time such as 3D transformations, parallax movement and CSS3 transitions.
While the site is not responsive (and is not intended to be), it does feature other best practices like Object-Oriented CSS, Sprite sheets, and SEO/Accessibility considerations.
The site you are at presently is designed to be responsive, but not leverage cutting edge (poorly supported) techniques.
A fun website I created by myself for a local bakery.  The structure is HTML5, the styling is CSS3, and the functionality is jQuery.
All design work including the logo are of my own creation.  Several pieces of print work, including stickers, stamps and aprons were created using this artwork.
I helped create and define the OnStar infotainment prototype, which later became Cadillac CUE and Chevy MyLink.
The prototype allowed for in-car Skype calls, camera sharing, collision cameras, and more.
Watch as the OnStar prototype is shown in this advertisement.
I helped define and program the API used by GM's infotainment systems.

This API allowed for wireless Internet sharing between the vehicle and a mobile device, and exposed data about the vehicle to any app which desired it, such as GPS, audio policies and even backseat monitors.
Applications shared between the radio and the mobile device could communicate with each other using a protocol I helped create.
Watch as Engadget uses and reviews this technology.
I helped program the applications running on the GM Connected Vehicle.
This vehicle connected through a mobile device's 4G hotspot.  All of the apps worked off of a JavaScript API that I helped to develop.
Users of this system could pair their mobile device (iOS and Android) with the vehicle and the vehicle would be able to communicate with applications on the mobile device.
Applications shared between the radio and the mobile device could communicate with each other using a protocol I helped create.
Watch as this technology is showcased at CES.
I helped define and program the API used by GM's infotainment systems.

This API allowed for wireless Internet sharing between the vehicle and a mobile device, and exposed data about the vehicle to any app which desired it, such as GPS, audio policies and even backseat monitors.
Applications shared between the radio and the mobile device could communicate with each other using a protocol I helped create.
Watch as the API I helped create is used by developers at Hackathon.
I helped create the MyLink in-dash infotainment system available in Chevrolet vehicles.
The API I helped to architect and program enables the MyLink system to perform phone-to-vehicle application sharing, such as Pandora, iHeartRadio, TuneIn Radio, weather, and many more.
Applications shared between the radio and the mobile device could communicate with each other using a protocol I helped create.
Watch as this technology is explained in further detail.
I helped define and program the API used by GM's infotainment systems.

This API allowed for wireless Internet sharing between the vehicle and a mobile device, and exposed data about the vehicle to any app which desired it, such as GPS, audio policies and even backseat monitors.
Applications shared between the radio and the mobile device could communicate with each other using a protocol I helped create.
Check out the article about this technology at Translogic.
I helped define and program the API used by GM's infotainment systems.

This API allowed for wireless Internet sharing between the vehicle and a mobile device, and exposed data about the vehicle to any app which desired it, such as GPS, audio policies and even backseat monitors.
Applications shared between the radio and the mobile device could communicate with each other using a protocol I helped create.
Check out the article about this technology at Autoblog.
My portfolio from 2011 is not impressive by today's standards.  In just a few short years, the techniques used have become obsolete and fallen out of favor.
However, this site still demonstrates the capacity for learning and the ability to keep up with evolving design and development trends that is vital to a successful web professional.
Yep - a Flash site.  The 2000s were a crazy time; no smart phones to worry about, responsive design didn't even exist, and jQuery was still emerging from a nuisance to a necessity.

It was built right, for the time, though.  The site is developed in ActionScript 3 with no timeline work being performed.  Each view is its own component with proper inheritence and struture, and the pubsub pattern is used to bubble and capture the necessary communications.
While this site is entirely obsolete, I still really enjoy the asthetics of it.
